query: The costs of monitoring copyright by states, artists, and lawyers far outweigh the benefits, and is often simply ineffective  The state incurs huge costs in monitoring for copyright infringement, in arresting suspected perpetrators, in imprisonment of those found guilty, even though in reality nothing was stolen but an idea that, once released to it, belonged to the public domain more or less. [1] Furthermore, the deterrent effect to copyright piracy generated by all the efforts of the state and firms has proven generally minimal. In fact, the level of internet piracy of books, music, and films has increased dramatically year on year for several years, increasing by 30% in 2011 alone. [2] This is because in many cases copyright laws are next to unenforceable, as the music and movie industries have learned to their annoyance in recent years, for example ninety percent of DVDs sold in China are bootlegs while even western consumers are increasingly bypassing copyright by using peer to peer networks. [3] Only a tiny fraction of perpetrators are ever caught, and though they are often punished severely in an attempt to deter future crime, it has done little to stop their incidence. Copyright, in many cases, does not work in practice plain and simple. Releasing works under a creative commons licensing scheme does a great deal to cope with these pressures. In the first instance it is a less draconian regime, so individuals are more willing to buy into it as a legitimate claim by artists rather than an onerous stranglehold on work. This increases compliance with the relaxed law. Secondly, the compliance means that artists are given the vocal crediting under the license rules that gives them more public exposure than clandestine copying could not. Ultimately this adaptation of current copyright law would benefit the artist and the consumer mutually.  [1] World Intellectual Property Organization. “Emerging Issues in Intellectual Property”. 2011   [2] Hartopo, A. “The Past, Present and Future of Internet Piracy”. Jakarta Globe. 26 July 2011.   [3] Quirk, M., “The Movie Pirates”, The Atlantic, 19 November 2009,
paraphrase: Releasing works under a Creative Commons licensing scheme helps combat piracy, especially when it provides greater protection for creators and encourages public exposure.

paraphrase:
The expenses associated with states, creators, and legal professionals tracking copyright violations exceed the advantages, frequently proving futile. Governments spend vast sums monitoring copyright infringements, apprehending suspects, and incarcerating those convicted, despite the fact that ideas, once shared, naturally belong to the public domain. Moreover, the measures taken by governments and companies to discourage copyright infringement have had limited effectiveness. For instance, internet piracy of literary works, music, and films has surged annually, with a 30% rise noted in 2011. This ineffectiveness is attributed to the difficulty in enforcing copyright laws; as evidenced by the film and music industries, where approximately 90% of DVDs in China are pirated copies, and Western consumers increasingly use peer-to-peer networks to circumvent copyright. The low capture rate of offenders, combined with harsh punishments intended to act as a deterrent, has had little impact on reducing such activities. In essence, copyright protection often fails in practical application.

Adopting a Creative Commons licensing model presents a viable solution to these challenges. Firstly, it offers a more lenient framework, encouraging greater acceptance among individuals who view it as a fair claim by artists rather than an oppressive control over their creations. This leads to higher compliance with the less restrictive regulations. Additionally, compliance ensures that artists receive proper credit as stipulated by the licensing terms, enhancing their public visibility compared to unauthorized distribution methods. Ultimately, this modification to current copyright practices would serve the interests of both artists and consumers alike.

query: Ill-informed prejudice has no place in society. The veneer of religion has been used to justify hatred, prejudice and division and should be confronted.  Homophobia is the last respectable prejudice [1] and should be tackled with the same passion and force that others have been, and continue to be, confronted. If the speaker had been condemning black people or women they would have been arrested for public disorder if they represented an organisation that was overtly racist, it would be quite likely to be banned.  For some reason Churches that hold views on homosexuality that are comparable in their vitriol to those on race held by neo-Nazi groups are not only tolerated but frequently supported by the state.  Hatred is hatred and there is no reason why homophobia should be given a free pass that would not be given to racism or sexism.  All of the Abrahamic faiths have, at their core, an authority focussed on maintaining ‘the natural order’. From the fourteenth century on – although interestingly less so before that point – homosexuality has been singled out as one of the gravest of sins [2] , with the Catechism identifying it as one of four sins that “calls out to Heaven for vengeance”. That is not merely offensive but dangerous in a modern society.  [1] Maguire, Daniel C., ‘Heterosexism in Contemporary World Religion’, The Religious Consultation.  [2] Boswell, John, The Marriage of Likeness, Harper Collins, Chapter Eight.
paraphrase: Unfounded bias should not find a home in our society. Religion's facade has often served to rationalize bigotry, discrimination, and discord, which must be challenged. Homophobia stands as the final socially acceptable bias and needs to be addressed with equal vigor and determination as other prejudices. Had the individual publicly denounced African Americans or females, charges of public disturbance would likely follow; organizations promoting such blatant racism might even face prohibition. Yet, religious institutions that express homophobic sentiments as intensely as neo-Nazi entities espouse racial animosity are often allowed to persist, sometimes even receiving government backing. Intolerance is intolerance, and there’s no justification for treating homophobia any differently than racism or misogyny. Throughout the Abrahamic traditions, there’s a fundamental emphasis on preserving what is deemed as 'natural order'. Starting from the 14th century, homosexuality began to be highlighted particularly as one of the most egregious offenses, with certain religious texts listing it among acts that provoke divine retribution. Such ideologies are not just insulting but also perilous in today's societal context.

query: Privacy  This was the clinching argument in the Dutch example. Labour MP Martijn van Dam, one of the bill’s co-authors said that Dutch ISP KPN was similar to “a postal worker who delivers a letter, looks to see what’s in it and then claims he hasn’t read it. It is simply a basic principle of the Internet that for it to continue working as it does now, all data needs to be treated the same otherwise judgements will be formed on ‘right’ and ‘wrong’ data [i] .  The principle here is that the data being used is simply none of the ISPs business. Their job is simply to provide an agreed bandwidth, at an agreed price to the end user. How the end user makes use of that band width is up to them. If, for example, they’re choosing to Skype from a mobile device – one of the points of contention – it’s hard to see what that has to do with the ISP.  [i] PCWorld. Matthew Honan, MacWorld. “Inside Net Neutrality: Privacy and BitTorrent. 14 February 2008.
paraphrase: In the Dutch context, this privacy aspect was decisive. Labour MP Martijn van Dam, one of the bill's co-authors, compared Dutch ISP KPN to "a postal worker who hands over a letter without inspecting its contents." The fundamental rule of the internet is that all data must be handled uniformly; otherwise, distinctions between 'right' and 'wrong' data would emerge. Essentially, the key idea is that the data in question is none of the ISP's concern. The sole role of the ISP is to supply the consumer with a stipulated bandwidth at a fixed price. Whether the user chooses to use this bandwidth to make a Skype call from a mobile device, for instance, is their prerogative. Thus, it is difficult to see how the ISP should intervene in such matters.
label: Valid

query: A South Ossetian state is unviable  There are many factors that make South Ossetia unviable as a state. South Ossetia is very small with a very small population. It is also a landlocked state and very poor. These facts make it unlikely that South Ossetia could act effectively as an independent state. The result is that it would become dependent on other states. [1] This can already be seen from the fact that S. Ossetia has only been able to secure its current de facto independence with substantial military and foreign aid from Russia. [2] S. Ossetia is economically unviable as an independent state. It is landlocked and only has meaningful road access to the sea through Georgia. S. Ossetian GDP was estimated at US$ 15 million (US$ 250 per capita) in a work published in 2002. S. Ossetia is arguably lacking in the basic economic necessities for autonomy. Indeed, a $15 million GDP would make South Ossetia one of the poorest nations in the world. Particularly following a war with Georgia in the 1990s, South Ossetia has struggled economically. Employment and supplies are scarce. The majority of the population survives on subsistence farming. Virtually the only significant economic asset that South Ossetia possesses is control of the Roki Tunnel that links Russia and Georgia, from which the South Ossetian government reportedly obtains as much as a third of its budget by levying customs duties on freight traffic. The separatist officials admitted that Tskhinvali received more than 60 percent of its 2006 budget revenue directly from the Russian government. [3] [4] Finally, S. Ossetia has a population of roughly 70,000. [5] This would make it one of the smallest states in the world. This fact, combined with its high level of poverty, makes it a poor candidate for independence, and shows that its “independence” would compel it to become even more dependent on Russia, or else risk disintegrating as an unviable state.  [1] BBC News. “S Ossetia votes for independence”. BBC News. 13 November 2006.   [2] Socor, Vladimir. “MOSCOW’S FINGERPRINTS ALL OVER SOUTH OSSETIA’S REFERENDUM”. Eurasia Daily Monitor Volume: 3 Issue: 212. The Jamestown Foundation. 15 November 2006.   [3] Walker, Shaun. “South Ossetia: Russian, Georgian...independent?”. Open Democracy. 15 November 2006.   [4] Vaisman, Daria. “No recognition for breakaway South Ossetia's vote”. The Christian Science Monitor. 10 November 2006.   [5] BBC News. “S Ossetia votes for independence”. BBC News. 13 November 2006.
paraphrase: Establishing South Ossetia as an independent state is impractical due to various constraints. Its diminutive size and sparse population pose significant challenges. As a landlocked region with limited economic resources, South Ossetia struggles to function autonomously. Consequently, it heavily relies on external assistance, particularly from Russia, to maintain its current status. This reliance is evident in the extensive military and diplomatic support South Ossetia receives from Russia. Economically, South Ossetia faces severe limitations; it depends on Georgia for any meaningful access to sea routes. With a gross domestic product estimated at just US$15 million (approximately US$250 per person) in 2002, it falls into the category of one of the most impoverished regions globally. The economic hardships are exacerbated by a scarcity of employment opportunities and supplies, forcing many inhabitants to rely on subsistence agriculture. The sole notable economic advantage lies in the Roki Tunnel, a crucial transit point between Russia and Georgia, contributing significantly to its budget through customs duties. Furthermore, financial support from Russia accounts for a considerable portion of its annual budget. With a population of about 70,000, South Ossetia remains one of the least populous regions, making it a weak candidate for sovereignty. This small populace, coupled with extreme poverty, underscores its dependency on Russia and raises doubts about its viability as an independent state.
label: Valid

query: Deeper issues unresolved  Microfinance provides a quick-fix solution for the poor. The individual, or community, is provided with a loan to invest in their future. However, although access to capital is a key concern for enabling entrepreneurialism it is not the silver bullet. Microfinance schemes will fail without providing a stable political and economic environment that makes a good climate to invest in.  Microfinance is essentially short-termist. It encourages investment but only in things that will bring a quick return. With interest rates as high as 30% the person taking the loan needs to pay it back as quickly as possible. This can sometimes be against an individual’s long term interests, for example access to microfinance often reduces primary school attendance as this is a long term investment that will not pay back the loan money (IOE, 2011).
paraphrase: The underlying problems remain unaddressed. While microfinance offers a swift remedy for poverty by extending loans to individuals or communities for future investments, it falls short of being the ultimate solution. Access to financial resources is crucial for fostering entrepreneurship, yet it is insufficient on its own. For microfinance initiatives to succeed, a solid political and economic framework that fosters a conducive investment atmosphere must be in place. Essentially, microfinance operates on a short-term basis, promoting investments that promise immediate returns. With interest rates soaring up to 30%, borrowers are pressured to repay loans rapidly. This urgency can conflict with long-term benefits; for instance, microfinance availability has been linked to decreased primary school enrollment, as investing in education is seen as a long-term endeavor that fails to directly repay the borrowed funds (IOE, 2011).
label: Valid

query: Prosecutions don't get to the real truth  Truth is the most important factor that supports the healing process. Individuals when being prosecuted have incentives to hide crimes and lie about the true motivations for offences occurring as they don’t want to go to prison for telling the truth. This means that the whole truth of matters never really come to light. TRC’s, such as that in South Africa, do a very good job of ensuring that the full record of human rights abuses come to light [1].The Rwandan Gacaca courts which encompasses three important features of relevance to broader experiments of reconciliatory justice serve as a lesson. Those who confess their crimes are rewarded with the halving of prison sentences and as a result, 60,238 prisoners have confessed to participating in the genocide [2]. Second, gacaca law highlights apologies welcomed by many as an important ingredient to promote reconciliation.  [1] Linfield, Susie, ‘Trading Truth for Justice? Reflections on South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission’, bostonreview,net, 01 June 2000,   [2] Graybill, Lyn, and Lanegran , Kimberly, ‘Truth, Justice, and Reconciliation in Africa: Issues and Cases’, ufl.edu, Fall 2004,
paraphrase: Prosecution does not reach the truth. The truth is the most important factor in supporting the healing process. People who are prosecuted do not want to tell the truth and try to hide the true motives of their crimes. This means that the truth is never revealed. TRCs, such as the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission, play a crucial role in uncovering the full record of human rights violations. The Gacaca Courts in Rwanda provide lessons for broader experiments in restorative justice. First, people who confess to participating in massacres receive a reduced prison sentence as a reward. As a result, 60,238 people confessed to participating in the massacres.[2] Second, the Gacaca Courts show that accepting an apology is an important factor in promoting reconciliation for many people.
label: Valid

query: Organ donors are more deserving of organs  Reciprocity is a basic moral principle: afford others the good treatment you yourself would like to receive. In most cases, it is a hypothetical; one must place oneself in the other person’s position even though one will never actually be in their place. However, how donor and non-donors are treated when they themselves are in need is a situation in which reciprocity becomes a practical reality. This principle of reciprocity suggests that people who are willing to donate their organs more deserve to receive organs when they need them. And there is good reason to believe in reciprocity. Those who would flaunt this principle are basically stating that they expect something of other people that they themselves are unwilling to do; this is a position that is either incoherent, or based on the unjustified premise that oneself is more objectively valuable than other people. The concept of desert has a foundational role in our society. For example, innocent people deserve not to be put in prison, even if it would be useful to frame and make an example of an innocent person in order to quell a period of civil unrest.
paraphrase: Individuals who consent to organ donation should have priority access to organs when needed. Reciprocity, a fundamental ethical rule, advocates treating others as you wish to be treated. Often, this rule is theoretical, requiring us to empathize with others despite never experiencing their exact circumstances. Yet, when it comes to organ allocation for donors versus non-donors, this concept of reciprocity translates into a real-world scenario. Reciprocity implies that those who choose to donate their organs upon death should receive higher priority for organ transplants when necessary. Upholding this principle is crucial because disregarding it implies expecting benefits from others while refusing to contribute oneself, which can only be seen as incoherent or arrogant. The idea of merit plays a significant role in societal norms; for instance, we believe that innocent individuals should not be incarcerated merely to serve as examples during times of social turmoil, despite potential temporary benefits.
label: Valid

query: Community radio evens the playing field against state and corporate broadcasters.  Autocracy has, at its root, the premise that only one perspective, or group of perspectives is legitimate. Certain assumptions are unquestionable, certain rules inviolable and, more often than not, certain voices unchallengeable.  It’s all too easy for that state of affairs to be normalised. Community radio offers another voice. More to the point it offers many.  As well as the value of the messages themselves, the very fact that they are there and broadcast is a powerful statement against autocratic assumptions. The process of establishing and running a community radio station is, in and of itself, a powerful fillip for community cohesion.  Giving voices to communities supports them as groups in their own right; cohesive, engaged and worthy of respect. In doing so it can provide a focus which increases the homogeneity of those communities without requiring the approval of a central structure of control [i] . In addition to well known examples such as Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, radio stations across the Middle East And, especially, Africa have been key movers in the shift to democracy [ii] .  [i] Siddharth. Riding the radio wave; Community radio in South-East Asia. Culture360.org 18 February 2010.  [ii] Buckley, Steve, President, World Association for Community Radio Broadcasters. Community Broadcasting: good practice in policy, law and regulation. UNESCO. 2008.
paraphrase: Community radio levels the broadcasting landscape by countering the dominance of state and corporate stations. At the heart of autocratic governance is the notion that only specific viewpoints hold validity, with no room for challenge or diversity. This can easily become the norm. Community radio introduces alternative narratives, emphasizing pluralism and diverse perspectives. Establishing and managing these stations fosters community solidarity and unity. By amplifying local voices, community radio empowers these groups, reinforcing their identity and respect. This process does not necessitate central oversight but rather enhances community coherence. Numerous instances, like Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, and particularly radio stations in the Middle East and Africa, have played pivotal roles in democratic transitions.
label: Valid

query: Vulnerable to unrest  Relying on tourism ensures that the economy is at the mercy of unrest. The violence and break down in law and order following the Tunisian revolution resulted in a notable decrease in tourists as tourists were unwilling to visit an area which they view as dangerous. This is demonstrated by the footfall of tourists which declined from 6,487,000 in 2010 to 4,456,000 in 2011 1. The increase in attacks by Salafists, a conservative sect of Islam which promotes Sharia law and has attacked tourist destinations, has dissuaded many potential visitors2. This has been exacerbated by government travel information which generally advises against visiting regions during periods of unrest, especially for Westerners who are perceived as profitable targets for ransom3. The resultant decrease in tourists reduces revenue, making tourism an unreliable industry for Tunisia.  1) African Manager, ‘Tunisia-Tourism: Clear Improvement, but a timid pace!’, data accessed 24 January 2014  2) Whewell,T. ‘Justice kiosk: Tunisia’s alternative law enforces’, BBC, 30 July 2013  3) Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ‘Kidnapping threat worldwide’
paraphrase: Dependent on visitor numbers, the economy suffers greatly due to social instability. Following the upheaval sparked by the Tunisian revolution, the surge in violence and chaos led to a significant drop-off in tourism, as travelers became hesitant to venture into what they deemed a perilous destination. Tourist visits fell sharply from 6,487,000 in 2010 to 4,456,000 in 2011. Additionally, the rise in assaults by Salafists, an Islamist group advocating for strict Sharia law and known for targeting tourist spots, further discouraged would-be visitors. This decline was worsened by travel advisories issued by governments warning citizens, particularly Western nationals seen as prime candidates for hostage situations, against traveling to unstable areas. Consequently, the loss in tourist revenue highlights the precarious nature of relying on tourism as a pillar of economic stability in Tunisia.
label: Valid

query: Human rights are dependent upon the state  There is clearly not universal or even widespread acceptance of the idea that internet access should be a human right. Human rights are dependent upon the state, the desires of the community, and that depends upon the state’s socio economic context. [1] The internet cannot therefore be considered a universal human right because not all states are advanced enough to take responsibility for this right.  International law is based upon several sources; state practice, customary law, treaties and judicial decisions. [2] None of these sources yet recognise internet access as a human right, indeed if state practice is taken as deciding if human rights exist then the whole concept of human rights is open to question. [3]  [1] Turkin, G., Theory of International Law, 1974, p.81  [2] Shaw, Malcolm N., International Law 4th ed., Cambridge University press, 1997, Chapter 3.  [3] Watson, J.S., Legal theory, efficacy and validity in the development of human rights norms in international law, University of Illinois law forum, 1979, p.609
paraphrase: Human rights hinge on governmental frameworks and societal norms, which vary widely across different nations. Consequently, the internet's status as a universal human right is questionable, given the differing levels of technological and infrastructural capabilities among states. Legal frameworks for human rights are established through state practices, customary laws, treaties, and court rulings. As none of these components currently recognize internet access as a fundamental right, it remains an unresolved issue. The concept of human rights could even be called into question if we rely solely on state actions to define them.
label: Valid

Human rights are dependent upon the state, the desires of the community, and that depends upon the state’s socio economic context. [1] The internet cannot therefore be considered a universal human right because not all states are advanced enough to take responsibility for this right.  International law is based upon several sources; state practice, customary law, treaties and judicial decisions. [2] None of these sources yet recognise internet access as a human right, indeed if state practice is taken as deciding if human rights exist then the whole concept of human rights is open to question. [3]  [1] Turkin, G., Theory of International Law, 1974, p.81  [2] Shaw, Malcolm N., International Law 4th ed., Cambridge University press, 1997, Chapter 3.  [3] Watson, J.S., Legal theory, efficacy and validity in the development of human rights norms in international law, University of Illinois law forum, 1979, p.609
paraphrase: Human rights depend on the state. There is no universal or widespread acceptance of the idea that internet access should be a human right. Human rights depend on the desires of the state, the community, and the socio-economic context of the state. Therefore, the internet cannot be a universal human right. International law is based on several sources. These include state practice, customary law, treaties, and judicial decisions. None of these sources recognizes internet access as a human right.
label: Valid

query: Development has many facets of which pure economic growth is a priority, especially in the context of a developing nation  It is a nation’s own sovereign decision to decide its own standards and pace itself. It is a sovereign right of self-determination of a nation to freely comply or refuse to comply with international standards. It is unfair to back a developing nation up against a wall and force them to ratify higher standards in return for aid.  It is notable that the countries that have developed fastest have often been those that have ignored the whims of the aid donors. The Asian tigers (Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, Taiwan, later followed by South East Asia and China) did not receive aid, but preserved authority over their developmental policies. Their success story does not involve the international labour standards and goes against many of the policy prescriptions, such as free trade, of international institutions, such as the World Bank and the ILO [1] . This shows that nations that follow their national interest rather than bending to the whims of donors are the ones that ultimately do best economically. These states only implement labour standards when they become beneficial; when it is necessary to build and maintain an educated labour force.  [1] Chang, Ha-Joon, “Infant Industry Promotion in Historical Perspective – A Rope to Hang Oneself or a Ladder to Climb With?”, a paper for the conference “Development Theory at the Threshold of the Twenty-first Century”, 2001,
paraphrase: The process of development encompasses various dimensions, with economic growth being a key focus, particularly for developing nations. Each country retains the sovereign right to determine its developmental trajectory and standards independently. It is within a nation's prerogative to choose whether to adhere to international standards or not. Coercing developing countries into accepting stringent international norms in exchange for assistance is unjust. Notably, some of the most rapidly developing nations have succeeded by disregarding the conditions set by aid providers. Countries like Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan, alongside others in Southeast Asia and China, achieved rapid growth without substantial foreign aid, maintaining control over their own development strategies. Their achievements contradict the advice typically offered by global financial entities such as the World Bank and the International Labour Organization, suggesting that prioritizing national interests can yield better economic outcomes. These countries tend to adopt labor standards only when it aligns with their economic benefits, specifically when necessary to cultivate and retain a skilled workforce.
label: Valid

query: This is an unjust use of unelected power  Politicians want endorsements because they know it will bring votes; it is estimated that Oprah’s endorsement of Obama in the Democratic Primary of 2008 brought an additional 1 million votes to Obama. [1] It is unjust for celebs to use their influence in this way. Celebrities have an ability to influence the political sphere that bears no necessary relationship with their knowledge of the subjects concerned, or qualifications otherwise to do so.  Consequently, they represent an unelected, unaccountable pressure on the democratic system: they have been given power and influence, with no mechanism of checking that power, or way to prevent them from misleading the public (unlike, for example, political journalists, news channels and other sources of political information).  This is principally unjust: the optimum democratic system is the one that holds the closest to the principle of “one person, one vote”, and attempts to ensure that those votes are as informed as possible. Celebrity involvement in politics is a hindrance to that, effectively handing the famous more votes than is their due.  [1] Garthwaite, Craig, and Moore, Timothy J., ‘Can Celebrity Endorsements Affect Political Outcomes? Evidence from the 2008 US Democratic Presidential Primary’, Journal of Law, Economics, and Organization, 2012,
paraphrase: This is an inappropriate use of unelected power by politicians who wish to secure popular support by using celebrity endorsements. According to research conducted in 2008, Oprah's campaign against Barack Obama in the Democratic National Convention was estimated to have contributed an additional 1 million votes to Obama. It is unjust that celebrities can utilize their power to sway elections. Celebrities' influence stems solely from their ability to shape societal perceptions rather than their specific knowledge of particular issues, which undermines checks and balances within the democratic system. This situation primarily represents injustice; an optimal democratic model prioritizes equality of all citizens while maintaining transparency. The use of celebrity endorsements negatively impacts voting outcomes by potentially giving celebrities an unfair advantage over ordinary voters.
label: Invalid

query: Coca chewing is not equivalent to the consumption of hard drugs. It is no more harmful than drinking coffee.  The coca leaf, in its natural state, is not even a narcotic, even though the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs considers the natural leaf to be so. However it only truly becomes a narcotic when the paste or the concentrate is extracted from the leaf to form cocaine. [1] The simple coca leaf, by contrast, only has very mild effects when chewed and is different from cocaine. In 1995 the World Health Organisation found that the “use of coca leaves appears to have no negative health effects and has positive therapeutic, sacred and social functions for indigenous Andean populations.” [2] It may even be useful in combating obesity, and there is no evidence that coca use is addictive. At worst, it is comparable to caffeine in terms of its effect on its consumer. [3] Therefore there are no significant health reasons behind this ban on the cultivation of coca leaves for their chewed consumption in its traditional form.  [1] Morales, Evo. “Let Me Chew My Coca Leaves”. New York Times. March 13, 2009.   [2] Jelsma, Martin. “Lifting the Ban on Coca Chewing”. Transnational Institute, Series on Legislative Reform of Drug Policies Nr. 11. March 2011.  [3] Morales, Evo. “Let Me Chew My Coca Leaves”. New York Times. March 13, 2009.
paraphrase: Chewing coca leaves does not equate to using hard drugs and is as harmless as drinking coffee. In its raw state, the coca leaf is not a narcotic; it is only classified as such under the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs due to legal definitions. When consumed naturally, the coca leaf has minimal effects and differs significantly from cocaine. A 1995 World Health Organization report indicated that coca leaf use shows no adverse health impacts and serves therapeutic, sacred, and social purposes for indigenous communities. Moreover, it might aid in weight management, and there's no proof of addiction. Thus, banning the cultivation of coca leaves solely for traditional chewing lacks substantial health justifications.
label: Valid

query: The desire for, and fight for, democracy must come from within or else democratic government will not be sustainable.  Unless the people within a country want democracy, they will not respect it. Unlike military dictatorships, democratic governments do not rely solely -- or even mainly-- on force to enforce the law. Rather, most people obey the law at least in part because they believe those laws are legitimate, as the result of free and fair elections. If citizens do not want such an electoral system, then there is no reason for them to obey the law, pay taxes etc. and the government will be unable to maintain order. Indeed, foreign-imposed democracies often slide back into authoritarian regimes because they find that they cannot uphold the law (at least without foreign support). Enterline and Greig found in a 2007 empirical study that half of imposed democracies fail within 30 years, and that this failure reduces the likelihood of democracy being successfully established in the future1/2.  1 Enterline, Andrew J. and Greig, J. Michael. "Against All Odds? Historical Trends in Imposed Democracy & the Future of Iraq &Afghanistan."  2 Doyle, Michael. "Promoting Democracy is Not Imposing Democracy." The Huffington Post.
paraphrase:
The aspiration for and pursuit of democratic principles must stem from the hearts and minds of the populace. If the majority does not wish for a democratic government, it would not function effectively. Unlike totalitarian dictatorship, democratic governments do not merely rely on force to enforce legal compliance but rather depend on citizen participation. Most individuals comply with laws primarily due to their belief that these laws are valid under free and fair elections. If the public does not desire a constitutional election process, it becomes pointless for them to adhere to existing laws and obligations, thus hampering the stability and legitimacy of governance.

It has been observed that foreign-imposed democracies often succumb rapidly, particularly if they lack sufficient support from other nations. In such cases, they may revert to authoritarian rule as they struggle to govern legally. Therefore, countries considering adopting imposed democratic models must be wary of potential downsides. Importantly, entering the field of international politics has revealed that imposing democratic forms can sometimes lead to the return of autocratic regimes, as they might find it difficult to maintain order without external intervention.
label: Invalid

query: Socialism has changed historically to meet the challenges of the moment and is addressing those of the 21st century in new ways  It should perhaps come as no surprise that the days of standing outside shopping centres and train stations handing out soggy newspapers have passed into the annals of political history – although some still do it.  Equally, trades union are no longer seen as being as central to European Socialism as they once were. However, the militancy seen over the last few years suggest, if anything, that what was a diversified ‘anti-capitalist’ movement is now coalescing around a rather clearer set of goals of which the basics of the anti-capitalism movement are merely a part. In the light of the globalisation of Capitalism, the left is increasingly rediscovering its internationalist roots which were lost to a great extent in the seventies and eighties in national struggles to save industries and jobs.
paraphrase: Socialism has historically adapted to meet the challenges of its time, and it is adapting in new ways to the challenges of the 21st century. Therefore, distributing wet newspapers outside shopping centers or train stations will no longer be recorded in political history. While some still do, of course. In addition, trade unions are no longer at the center of European socialism as they were in the 1970s and 1980s. However, the intense actions of recent years have shown that the basic principles of the anti-capitalist movement are more than just a few. Capitalism's globalization has caused the left to rediscover its internationalist roots lost in the 1970s and 1980s.
label: Valid

Nevertheless, recent activism indicates a growing alignment towards more specific objectives, with anti-capitalist sentiments serving as a foundational element. As capitalism becomes globally integrated, the leftist movements are rekindling their internationalist ideologies, which were somewhat dormant during the 1970s and 80s, focusing on national industrial and job preservation efforts.

query: The New START treaty will help against Iran’s nuclear program.  New START will help bolster US-Russian cooperation, which is necessary for solving the problem of Iran’s nuclear proliferation. On Nov. 19, 2010, the Anti-Defamation League released a statement, which came from Robert G. Sugarman, ADL National Chair, and Abraham H. Foxman, ADL National Director: "The severe damage that could be inflicted on that relationship by failing to ratify the treaty would inevitably hamper effective American international leadership to stop the Iranian nuclear weapons program. The Iranian nuclear threat is the most serious national security issue facing the United States, Israel, and other allies in the Middle East. While some Senators may have legitimate reservations about the New START treaty or its protocol, we believe the interest of our greater and common goal of preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons must take precedence." [1] New START is crucial in getting Russian support against Iran and other rogue nuclear states.  Although the United States needs a strong and reliable nuclear force, the chief nuclear danger today comes not from Russia but from rogue states such as Iran and North Korea and the potential for nuclear material to fall into the hands of terrorists. Given those pressing dangers, some question why an arms control treaty with Russia matters. It matters because it is in both parties' interest that there be transparency and stability in their strategic nuclear relationship. It also matters because Russia's cooperation will be needed if we are to make progress in rolling back the Iranian and North Korean programs. Russian help will be needed to continue our work to secure "loose nukes" in Russia and elsewhere. And Russian assistance is needed to improve the situation in Afghanistan, a breeding ground for international terrorism.  Obviously, the United States does not sign arms control agreements just to make friends. Any treaty must be considered on its merits. But the New START agreement is clearly in the US’ national interest, and the ramifications of not ratifying it could be significantly negative. [2] As US Vice President Joe Biden argued in 2010: "New Start is also a cornerstone of our efforts to reset relations with Russia, which have improved significantly in the last two years. This has led to real benefits for U.S. and global security. Russian cooperation made it possible to secure strong sanctions against Iran over its nuclear ambitions, and Russia canceled a sale to Iran of an advanced anti-aircraft missile system that would have been dangerously destabilizing. Russia has permitted the flow of materiel through its territory for our troops in Afghanistan. And—as the NATO-Russia Council in Lisbon demonstrated—European security has been advanced by the pursuit of a more cooperative relationship with Russia. We should not jeopardize this progress." [3] Therefore, because New START will have significant positive consequences in terms of aiding relations with Russia, and thus in dealing with rogue nuclear states like Iran, it should be supported.  [1] Weingarten, Elizabeth. “How did New START become a Jewish issue?”. The Atlantic. 1 Decemebr 2010.   [2] Kissinger, Henry A. ; Shultz, George P. ; Baker III, James A’ ; Eagleburger , Lawrence S. ; and Powell, Colin L. "The Republican case for ratifying New START". Washington Post. 2 December 2010.   [3] Biden, Joseph. "The case for ratifying New START". Wall Street Journal. 25 November 2010.
paraphrase: The ratification of the New START treaty is vital for addressing the Iranian nuclear threat, as it enhances US-Russian collaboration, essential for curbing Iran’s proliferation activities. Without it, there could be substantial setbacks in achieving effective international leadership against Iran’s nuclear ambitions. The treaty serves mutual interests by promoting transparency and stability in nuclear relations, which is critical for countering rogue states like Iran and North Korea, and for preventing nuclear materials from falling into terrorist hands. The success in securing Russian support underscores the importance of New START, particularly given its role in facilitating robust international cooperation, as exemplified by joint actions on Iran and Afghanistan. Hence, supporting New START is imperative for advancing global security and countering nuclear proliferation threats.
label: Valid

By enhancing collaboration between the U.S. and Russia, New START facilitates the tackling of Iran's nuclear expansion issues. On November 19, 2010, the Anti-Defamation League issued a statement, co-signed by Robert G. Sugarman and Abraham H. Foxman, asserting that failing to ratify the treaty would strain the U.S.-Russian partnership, complicating America's international efforts to curb Iran's nuclear weapon development. They emphasized that preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons is a paramount security concern for the U.S., Israel, and allied nations in the Middle East. Despite certain senators having valid concerns regarding the treaty, the priority of halting Iran's nuclear capabilities should overshadow these doubts. New START is critical for gaining Russian backing against Iran and similar regimes. Although the U.S. must maintain a robust nuclear defense, current threats mainly stem from rogue states like Iran and North Korea, alongside the risk of nuclear materials falling into terrorist hands. Critics might wonder why an arms reduction pact with Russia is important, yet transparency and stability in their nuclear interactions benefit both nations. Moreover, Russian cooperation is indispensable for tackling Iran and North Korea's nuclear programs, securing unsecured nuclear materials, and enhancing conditions in Afghanistan, a hotbed for global terrorism. Clearly, arms control treaties aren't merely about fostering goodwill; they must serve national interests. In this context, New START aligns with the U.S.'s best interests, and its non-ratification could lead to significant drawbacks. As Vice President Joe Biden contended in 2010, New START serves as a foundation for reviving U.S.-Russia ties, yielding actual benefits for American and worldwide security. Russian support was pivotal in imposing sanctions on Iran's nuclear pursuits and halting the sale of sophisticated missile systems to Iran, which posed a considerable threat. Additionally, Russia facilitated supplies to U.S. forces in Afghanistan and contributed to advancing European security through the NATO-Russia Council meeting in Lisbon. Thus, rejecting the potential gains from New START would be ill-advised.
label: Valid

query: The decision to die is a deeply personal one - it is no business of the state.  Ultimately, the decision to die is a personal one, it may affect others but, clearly it has the greatest impact on the person who decides to die.  Clearly those who remain behind will have to deal with the consequences of that death and the end of their relationship with that person but, one would hope, that would be the case if she had died of natural causes at a later date. Furthermore the experience of watching someone die can by as traumatic, or more so, for the carer or loved one than it is for the individual concerned.  What it clearly is not, is an issue for legislators and other strangers who have no connection to the person involved. There are deeply personal issues such as love, death, sex, and reproduction where we accept the state may have a role in the formal sense of preventing their abuse but otherwise should not have an opinion either way. With the right to die the state has maintained not only an opinion but a criminal sanction. This is a clear example of where the role of the state is to respect the individual and step back; legislation is far too cumbersome a tool with be used in circumstances as varied and complex as these.  Dealing with the loss of a loved one, particularly in a situation such as assisted suicide, is painful and traumatic enough for all concerned without adding to that the additional stress of a threat of criminal sanction.
paraphrase: The choice to end one's life is fundamentally a private matter—it shouldn't concern the government. Ultimately, this decision is highly personal and primarily affects the individual making it, although it certainly impacts those left behind. Ideally, these lingering effects would be similar to those experienced if the person had passed away from natural causes later in life. It's important to acknowledge that witnessing someone's death can often be just as distressing, or even more so, for family members or caregivers compared to the person going through it. This isn't a matter for lawmakers and outsiders disconnected from the individual's situation. In cases like love, death, sexuality, and procreation, society typically agrees that the state should intervene only to prevent misuse, but otherwise, refrain from imposing opinions. Yet, regarding the right to die, the state imposes not just an opinion but also criminal penalties. Here, the government’s role should be to uphold individual rights and retreat; laws are too rigid to address such diverse and intricate scenarios. For everyone involved, coping with the loss of a loved one, especially in contexts involving assisted dying, is already profoundly difficult, without the added strain of potential legal repercussions.
label: Valid

paraphrase:
The decision to commit suicide, while a deeply personal event, falls within the realm of individual autonomy. It affects none outside of oneself and impacts only the person making this decision, leaving it entirely up to them to decide how they wish to live their life. 

While some individuals might seek out help when faced with the decision to commit suicide due to the potential dangers associated with assisted dying, the majority do not rely solely on state intervention to guide their actions. The experiences of those affected by suicide often involve profound emotional pain, which requires professional support and possibly medical care.

In many cases, the consequences of suicide are more severe than those of a legal death through assisted dying. They often result in physical trauma, mental health issues, and societal ostracization. Therefore, it's essential to remember that the decision itself is personal, and the state plays a crucial role in supporting those experiencing these difficult situations.

It's true that legislative bodies must consider various factors, including the specific context and circumstances surrounding the individual's situation. However, this does not necessarily mean they cannot intervene when necessary to protect public safety and human dignity. Legislation can also play a critical role in mitigating the psychological impact of suicide, providing resources and support systems for the bereaved and advocating for policies that promote healing and support for families dealing with grief.

Ultimately, the choice to commit suicide carries significant personal implications, requiring close examination from both a moral and ethical standpoint. While the government has a responsibility to ensure that the decision-making process is conducted ethically and with due regard for the welfare of the affected individuals, the individual themselves bears ultimate responsibility for their own actions.

query: In the current environment, moves to make English the official language are specifically targeted at Hispanic immigrants  Historically, efforts to declare English the official language tend to come up when certain elements in the American body politic become threatened. It became an issue in the First World War, when resentment rose against German immigrants, and the present movement, though nominally not signalling anyone out, is clearly aimed at Hispanics.  This can be inferred from the fact that they are by far the largest non-English linguistic group in the country, and on occasion such views have been let slip, as the leader of one of the largest lobbying groups for a National Language did.[1]  Even if such legislation is not aimed specifically at Hispanics, everyone will assume that it is, and many Hispanics will nevertheless believe that they are the intended targets.  The practical result of this will be the alienation of the Hispanic population as many Hispanics see themselves under attack, which will cause many Hispanics to concentrate together, undermining many of the arguments for assimilation the government has made.  Furthermore, to the extent it stigmatizes Spanish speakers as the ‘other’, it may well encourage bullying against Hispanic students, and discrimination against those who can’t speak English, who are a far larger group than those who chose not to speak it.  [1] ‘English Only Movement FAQ File’, Mass. English Plus,
paraphrase: The current push to make English the official language is specifically targeting Hispanic immigrants. Historically, movements to make English the official language have occurred when certain elements of the U.S. political system have been threatened. This was the case during World War I, when anger toward German immigrants grew. The current movement is not explicitly targeting anyone, but many Hispanic immigrants will feel they are being attacked.
label: Invalid

query: Internet access as a new human right.  Access to the internet can be considered a separate human right in and of itself. The UN special rapporteur in June 2011 published a report that implied that access to the internet is a human right “The Special Rapporteur remains concerned that legitimate online expression is being criminalized in contravention of States' international human rights obligations.” [1]  The right to internet access can meet the necessary conditions to be a human right; as a right is should be universal, everyone should have access not just a few. The internet is becoming much more than just a tool but is becoming a fundamental part of society creating a new sphere of interaction that everyone has a right to have access to.  Creating a right to internet access would be addressing a specific contemporary problem as with other human rights that are specific such as a right to basic schooling, enshrined in article 26 of the Universal Declaration of Human rights. Not having access to the internet is similar to not having basic schooling; it considerably narrows people’s options and their horizons. As Tim Berners-Lee, the founder of the world wide web, argues "Given the many ways the web is crucial to our lives and our work, disconnection is a form of deprivation of liberty." [2]  [1] La Rue, Frank, Report of the Special Rapporteur on the promotion and protection of the right to freedom of opinion and expression, Human Rights Council, Seventeenth session, A/HRC/17/27, 16 May 2011, p.10 .  [2] Burkeman, Oliver, ‘Inside Washington’s high risk mission to beat web censors’, guardian.co.uk, 15 April 2012.
paraphrase: The right to access the Internet is a new human right. The right to access the Internet can be considered a separate human right in its own right. In June 2011, the UN Special Rapporteur on the Promotion and Protection of the Right to Freedom of Opinion and Expression released a report stating that the right to access the Internet was being criminalized, violating a state's international human rights obligations. "The Special Rapporteur believes that the right to access the Internet meets the necessary conditions to be considered a human right. Access to the Internet should not be limited to a few people; it should be available to everyone. The Internet is creating new areas of society, and like other human rights, such as basic education, everyone should have access to it."
label: Valid

query: We have a duty to protect individuals from the worst reactions to art  Those who see the artwork, or hear of it, must be considered. Often, social disgust stems from the violation of those values that are most central to an individual.  An individual’s right not to have their most central values abused or ridiculed is surely of more importance than the desire of an artist to be entirely unrestricted in their work: the harm caused to individuals by the continuing acceptance by society, (and consequent exposure) of art they find disgusting, can be great, and the reasonable modern society recognises such harms and does not impose them unnecessarily.  For example, the case of the Chapman brothers’ repeated use of Hitler and Nazi imagery: for the Chapmans the horror of WW2 might be distant and historical, and therefore for them the time may have come for Hitler to simply be mocked; however, for others that horror is altogether more current. Other people may feel a greater connection, for example, because of the impact on their close family, which cannot simply be ignored. In a situation like this, clearly the impact is infinitely more negative for that individual whose trauma is, in effect, being highlighted as now acceptable for comic material, than the positive gain is for the Chapmans: if restricted, they are simply caused to move on to other subjects.
paraphrase: We owe it to people to shield them from the most distressing effects of art. When art is presented or discussed, its impact on individuals must be taken into account. Social disgust often arises from the infringement of deeply held personal values. The right of an individual not to have their core beliefs desecrated should be prioritized over an artist's unrestricted freedom. The potential harm inflicted on individuals by continually exposing them to content they find abhorrent is significant, and a responsible society acknowledges these harms and avoids imposing them unless absolutely necessary. For instance, the Chapman brothers' recurring use of Hitler and Nazi imagery highlights this issue. While the Chapman brothers might view World War II as history and feel it's time to mock Hitler, many others still grapple with the immediacy and personal impact of that trauma. Their discomfort is far greater than any potential benefit to the artists in terms of artistic expression. If the art is restricted, the artists merely shift their focus to other themes.
label: Valid

query: Genetically modified organisms can solve the problem of food supply in the developing world.  The possible benefits from GM food are enormous. Modifications which render plants less vulnerable from pests lead to less pesticide use, which is better for the environment. Other modifications lead to higher crop yield, which leads to lower food prices for all. However, This technology really comes into its own in developing countries. Here where water is at a shortage, modifications (which lead crops to needing less water), are of vital importance. The World Health Organization predicts that vitamin A deficiency, with the use of GMOs, could be wiped out rapidly in the modern world. The scientists developed the strain of rice, called “golden rice”, which produces more beta-carotene and this way produces 20 times more vitamins than other strains, creating a cure for childhood blindness in developing countries. [1]  The fact that it has not is illustrative of the lack of political and economic will to solve these problems. GM food provides a solution that does not rely on charity from Western governments. As the world population increases and the environment deteriorates further this technology will become not just useful but necessary.  [1] Black R., GM “golden rice” boosts vitamin A, published 03/25/2005,  , accessed 09/02/2011
paraphrase: Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can help solve the food supply problem in developing countries. The potential benefits of GMOs are enormous. Modifications that make crops more resistant to pests reduce the need for pesticides, which benefits the environment. Other modifications increase crop yields, lowering food prices for everyone. However, this technology is crucial in developing countries, where drought-resistant crops are essential. The World Health Organization (WHO) predicts that genetically modified crops could quickly eradicate vitamin A deficiency in the modern world. The "golden rice," a genetically modified rice that contains 20 times more beta-carotene, is known as the "golden rice."

query: Deeper issues unresolved  Microfinance provides a quick-fix solution for the poor. The individual, or community, is provided with a loan to invest in their future. However, although access to capital is a key concern for enabling entrepreneurialism it is not the silver bullet. Microfinance schemes will fail without providing a stable political and economic environment that makes a good climate to invest in.  Microfinance is essentially short-termist. It encourages investment but only in things that will bring a quick return. With interest rates as high as 30% the person taking the loan needs to pay it back as quickly as possible. This can sometimes be against an individual’s long term interests, for example access to microfinance often reduces primary school attendance as this is a long term investment that will not pay back the loan money (IOE, 2011).
paraphrase: Addressing deeper problems remains unachieved. Microfinance serves as a temporary remedy for those in poverty by offering loans for potential growth. Nevertheless, while financial access is crucial for fostering entrepreneurship, it does not solve all issues. For microfinance initiatives to succeed, a solid political and economic backdrop must be established to create favorable conditions for investments. Essentially, microfinance operates on a short-term basis. It promotes investments but only in ventures promising swift returns. Given that interest rates may reach up to 30%, individuals are compelled to repay loans rapidly. This urgency can conflict with longer-term personal gains, such as decreased enrollment in primary education due to its nature as an investment with delayed benefits (IOE, 2011).
label: Valid

query: The double burden  Despite a feminising labour market there has been no convergence, or equalisation, in unpaid domestic and care work. Women still play key roles in working the reproductive sphere and family care; therefore labour-force participation increases the overall burden placed on women. The burden is placed on time, physical, and mental demands.  We need to recognise the anxieties and burdens women face of being the bread-winner, as survival is becoming ‘feminised’ (Sassen, 2002). Additionally, women have always accounted for a significant proportion of the labour market - although their work has not been recognised. Therefore to what extent can we claim increased labour force participation is empowering when it is only just being recognised?
paraphrase: The dual challenge persists despite shifts towards more female-dominated employment sectors; there remains no reduction in the unequal distribution of unpaid household and caregiving responsibilities. Women continue to dominate the non-economic sphere of nurturing and family care, which amplifies their overall workload with increased professional commitments. This workload imposes significant temporal, physical, and psychological pressures. It's imperative to acknowledge the fears and stresses women endure as they take on both earning and caregiving roles, making subsistence increasingly "female-oriented" (Sassen, 2002). Furthermore, women's contributions to the workforce, though substantial, have often gone unrecognized. Hence, how valid is the notion of empowerment through higher labor force participation when these efforts are only recently being appreciated?
label: Valid

query: A UN standing army is simply impossible to form.  A standing army for the United Nations has an existing legal framework; it has never been attempted in practice because it would be impossible to create. Article 43 of the original UN Charter specifies that all member states are expected, upon the signing of a future UN agreement, to provide ‘forces, assistance and facilities’ for the maintenance of international peace and security 1. That it is has never been attempted is the direct result of its sheer impracticality; who would contribute the troops? How would they be trained, and ensure that troops trained in one state would not be asked to thereafter fire on their own colleagues? Furthermore, where would the U.N. standing army be located, for the United Nations has no land, and the United States would not take kindly to a reprisal attack on the UN Army at the United Nations Headquarters. And who would fund this army? The United States hasn’t paid its bills to the United Nations in years due to their opposition to some of its actions/ What is there in place to prevent that continuing? Lastly, and most importantly, whose will would they be implementing, for the United Nations is not a single voice but the aggregated noise of its member states? The Security Council, which currently dictates the form that U.N. peacekeeping operations take, are not a group to whom impartiality can be attributed. A U.N standing army at the behest of the Security Council would be used sparingly at best and only in regions and conflicts for whom all the P5 had a vested interest in the maintenance of peace. Any impartiality that the U.N. standing army had in theory would be lost in practice.  1. U.N. Charter, (1945)
paraphrase: A UN standing army is impractical given the current legal and logistical constraints. The UN Charter mandates member states to provide forces for peacekeeping, but this has never been realized due to the monumental challenges involved. Who would supply the troops, and how could they be trained without risking internal conflicts within nations? Additionally, with the UN lacking physical territory, where could such an army be based? Moreover, funding would be problematic, considering the USA's arrears and reluctance to support UN initiatives. Finally, the diverse interests of member states, particularly those of the P5 on the Security Council, would make any unified command and control structure untenable, eroding any potential impartiality.
label: Invalid

query: Authoritarian leadership  President Kagame though considered a visionary leader has made Rwanda a country based on one man’s ideas. He has silenced critics, opposition and any counter arguments that may not support his opinions through tough rules imposed against the media and free speech. This sparked misunderstandings within the government forcing 4 four high rank officials in exile, one, an ex-intelligence chief was recently murdered in South Africa[1].  Rwanda is essentially a hard-line, one-party, secretive police state with a façade of democracy[2]. To avoid future conflict and government break down Kagame needs to convene a genuine, inclusive, unconditional and comprehensive national dialogue with the aim of preparing and strengthening the country’s future progress.  The fact that most Rwandans still want him to run for re-election after his two terms in 2017 shows how much he has controlled people to believe he is the only potential leader in a country of more than 11 million citizens. If Rwanda is to have a stable future democracy it needs to be recognised that the opposition are patriots too and should be entitled to freedom of speech and press to give them an opportunity to share their views on how the country can be improved. For democracy in Rwanda to progress the country needs to accept the idea of freedom of speech and a ‘loyal opposition’.[3]  [1] Aljazeera Africa news, ‘Rwandan ex-spy chief found dead in S Africa’, Aljazeera.com, 2 January 2014  [2] Kenzer, Stephen, ‘Kagame's authoritarian turn risks Rwanda's future’, thegurdian.com, 27 January 2011  [3] Fisher, Julie, ‘Emerging Voices: Julie Fisher on Democratization NGOs and Loyal Opposition’, CFR, 13 March 2013
paraphrase: President Kagame, despite being viewed as a forward-thinking leader, has established Rwanda as a nation that adheres strictly to his personal ideologies. Critics and opposing viewpoints have been suppressed through stringent regulations on media and public discourse. Such actions have led to conflicts within the government, pushing four high-ranking officials into exile, including a former intelligence head who was tragically killed in South Africa. Essentially, Rwanda operates under a rigid, single-party regime that maintains an image of democracy while exercising authoritative control. In order to prevent internal strife and governmental instability, Kagame must initiate a truthful, all-encompassing dialogue with every segment of society to ensure the nation's continued advancement. The desire of many Rwandans for Kagame to seek re-election beyond his two terms in 2017 suggests a significant level of manipulation where he is seen as indispensable by a populace of over 11 million. Genuine democratic progress requires recognizing the legitimacy of the opposition and granting them the rights to freedom of expression and press, allowing diverse perspectives on national improvement. It is imperative for Rwanda to embrace the concept of a 'loyal opposition' for democracy to truly flourish.
label: Valid

query: Legitimacy  In extreme cases, in which peaceful and democratic methods have been exhausted, it is legitimate and justified to resort to terror. In cases of repression and suffering, with an implacably oppressive state and no obvious possibility of international relief, it is sometimes necessary to resort to violence to defend one’s people and pursue one’s cause.  Every individual or (minority) group has the right to express its discontent. The state, being a representation of the people, should facilitate this possibility. Even more, the state should support the rights of minorities, in order to prevent the will of the majority suppressing the rights of people with other interests. If this does not happen, the state has failed to serve its purpose and loses its legitimacy. This, in combination with the growing inequalities and injustices amongst certain groups, justifies committing acts of terror in order to defend these rights, that were denied in the first place.  For instance, Umkhonto we Sizwe, a liberation organisation associated with the African National Congress in South Africa and led by Nelson Mandela, decided in 1961 to turn to violence in order to achieve liberation and the abolishment of Apartheid. The reason they gave was:  “The time comes in the life of any nation when there remain only two choices: submit or fight. That time has now come to South Africa. (...) Refusal to resort to force has been interpreted by the government as an invitation to use armed force against the people without any fear of reprisals. The methods of Umkhonto we Sizwe mark a break with that past.” [1]  [1] African National Congress. (1961, December 16). Manifesto. Retrieved August 3, 2011, from African National Congress:
paraphrase: In dire circumstances where peaceful avenues have been fully exploited and met with relentless oppression, it is permissible and warranted to employ terror. When a state shows unyielding cruelty without any viable international assistance, violence may become essential for protecting one's populace and advocating for one's cause. Each individual or minority has the right to voice dissatisfaction. The state, representing the populace, must ensure these rights are upheld. Furthermore, the state should champion minority rights to avoid the majority overshadowing others' interests. Should it fail in this duty, the state forfeits its legitimacy. This, coupled with increasing disparities and injustices, can justify using terror to safeguard rights initially denied. For example, Umkhonto we Sizwe, linked to the African National Congress in South Africa under Nelson Mandela's leadership, chose violence in 1961 to attain freedom and dismantle apartheid. They argued, "There comes a point in the life of any nation when it faces only two options: submission or resistance. That moment has arrived in South Africa." [1] [1] African National Congress. (1961, December 16). Manifesto. Retrieved August 3, 2011, from African National Congress:
label: Valid

Every individual or (minority) group has the right to express its discontent. The state, being a representation of the people, should facilitate this possibility. Legitimacy is upheld when, after all non-violent and democratic avenues are explored, turning to terror becomes a justified course of action. "The moment arrives for every nation where only two paths lie ahead: capitulation or combat. This juncture has now arisen in South Africa. (...) The government has misconstrued our reluctance to engage in force as a green light to deploy violent measures against the populace with impunity. The tactics of Umkhonto we Sizwe signify a departure from the preceding era." [1]

query: PMCs have an interest in conflict.  ncreased reliance on mercenaries is destabilising in the long term. It allows invaders and local governments to feel that they can get away with not providing sufficiently trained or numerous security forces because there are men on the ground. It also means that the most influential actors, large multi-national companies, no longer have to pressure governments so hard to provide security guarantees for everyone because they can buy their own. That leaves those without influence or money high and dry. This then leads to a proliferation of armed forces in the country, some working for the central government, others for local governments and some for private individuals and firms. These PMCs are hired provide security and to help create stability yet that is not where their interests lie. If the country returns to stability they are out of a job so it is in their interest to keep an unstable situation unstable to result in more work. (Wennmann, 2008)
paraphrase: PMCs have a vested interest in maintaining conflict. The increased use of mercenaries contributes to long-term instability by making it seem acceptable for both invaders and local governments to under-rescue or inadequately train their security forces. Moreover, powerful multinational corporations can now rely on private military contractors rather than pressing governments for robust security assurances. This leaves those with less influence or resources at a disadvantage. As a consequence, there is a growing array of armed groups operating within a nation—some aligned with the central government, others with regional authorities, and still others with private entities. While these contractors are employed to foster security and stability, their true motives often lie elsewhere. In a stable environment, they lose their purpose, thus incentivizing them to maintain or even perpetuate instability to ensure continued employment. (Wennmann, 2008)
label: Valid

query: Artists should retain the right to control their work’s interaction with the public space even if their work is publicly funded  Art is the expression of its creator’s sense of understanding of the world, and thus that expression will always have special meaning to him or her that no amount of reinterpretation or external appreciation can override. How a work is used once released into the public sphere, whether expanded, revised, responded to, or simply shown without their direct consent, thus remains an active issue for the artist, because those alternative experiences are all using a piece of the artist in its efforts. Artists deserve to have that piece of them treated in a way they see as reasonable. It is a simple matter of justice that artists be permitted to maintain the level of control they desire, and it is a justice that is best furnished through the conventional copyright mechanism that provides for the maximum protection of works for their creators, and allows them to contract away uses and rights to those works on their own terms. Many artists care about their legacies and the future of their artistic works, and should thus have this protection furnished by the state through the protection of copyright, not cast aside by the unwashed users of the creative commons. Samuel Beckett is a great example of this need. Beckett had exacting standards about the fashion in which in his plays could be performed. [1] For him the meaning of the art demanded an appreciation for the strict performance without the adulteration of reinterpretation. He would lack that power under this policy, meaning either the world would have been impoverished for want of his plays, or he would have been impoverished for want of his rights to his work. These rights are best balanced through the aegis of copyright as it is, not under the free-for-all of the creative commons license.  [1] Catron, L. “Copyright Laws for Theatre People”. 2003.
paraphrase: Artists must have the authority to oversee how their creations engage with the public domain, even when these works benefit from public financial support. Since art embodies the artist's interpretation of the world, it inherently carries a unique significance to the creator, a value that cannot be diminished or altered by external interpretations or appreciations. Once an artwork enters the public realm, how it is utilized—whether through alterations, responses, or unauthorized presentations—remains a critical concern for the artist, as these actions involve aspects of the artist's identity. It is justifiable for artists to expect their works to be handled in accordance with their approval, which is most effectively safeguarded via traditional copyright laws designed to offer creators comprehensive protection over their works, enabling them to decide independently over the distribution and usage rights of their creations. Many artists prioritize their reputations and the future of their art, warranting such protections provided by the state through copyright legislation rather than being disregarded by unrestricted use within the creative commons. An illustrative example is Samuel Beckett, who stipulated precise conditions for the performances of his plays, underscoring the necessity for artists to govern the presentation of their art. If Beckett's rights were compromised, it would either lead to a void in cultural offerings due to his plays' non-performance or deprive him of the benefits tied to his creative rights. The current copyright framework offers the optimal balance of protection, unlike the unregulated environment of the creative commons.
label: Valid

paraphrase: Artists should preserve the authority to manage how their creations engage with public spaces, even when their work receives public funding. Therefore, it is crucial that artists can dictate how their works are utilized, ensuring these uses align with their intended message. This is a fundamental principle of justice, and it can be effectively upheld through copyright law, which offers comprehensive protections tailored to the artist's wishes. Copyright not only safeguards artists' rights but also permits them to negotiate and limit the use of their works according to their preferences. Many artists are deeply invested in their legacies and the preservation of their art, necessitating state-provided copyright protection rather than relinquishing such rights to open-source platforms like Creative Commons. Samuel Beckett exemplifies the importance of this; he insisted on precise staging techniques for his plays, viewing any deviation from his specifications as detrimental to the true essence of his work. Under a system that disregards such individual authorship rights, either Beckett's plays would be neglected, or he would lose the ability to protect his artistic integrity. Copyright, in its current form, provides the optimal balance for protecting these rights, whereas the Creative Commons model lacks this nuanced control.
label: Valid

query: Capital punishment is a comparatively small issue  Whatever the merits, capital punishment in Africa is a small issue. Capital punishment opponents should focus on China, which uses capital punishment in a secretive manner for all variety of offences and executes far more people than the rest of the world put together. [1]  If Western human rights groups genuinely want to improve human rights in Africa, there are a myriad of issues that affect many more people relating to good governance, political rights and socio-economic rights, rather than just focusing on a small number of individuals, generally convicted of particularly serious criminal offences.  [1] ‘Death Sentences and Executions 2012’, Amnesty International, April 2013,  , p.6
paraphrase: Capital punishment is a minor concern in Africa. Those opposed to it would do better to concentrate on China's secretive use of capital punishment for diverse offenses, where the number of executions vastly exceeds those in the rest of the world combined. If Western human rights organizations truly aim to enhance human rights in Africa, they should address numerous other issues, such as good governance, political freedoms, and socio-economic rights, rather than concentrating on a few individuals typically convicted of severe crimes. [1] 'Death Sentences and Executions 2012', Amnesty International, April 2013, p.6
label: Valid
